Everyone has a curiosity template. Our curiosity template speaks to the fundamental interest that we have in other people and the world.

Some people are more drawn to the personal, the “who are you?” questions.

Some people are more interested in the practical. The “what are you doing and why does it matter?” questions.

Some people are more fascinated by the intellectual. The “what do you know about the world?” questions.

Some people are intrigued by the topical. The “what do you think about this thing?” questions.

Your “Big Five” are the five questions that you find yourself to be generally interested to know about anyone you meet. It could be a coworker, friend or family member.

Take some time to establish your “ Big Five” and watch your conversations transform.

They make it easier to walk in any room and know that we have something of value to contribute.

The quality of our life is directly correlated with the conversations we are having.

With ourselves and the people we meet.

Better questions = better conversations.

This was the final message I shared with our meditation accountability group today. 250 people challenged themselves to meditate for 30-days straight.

“A setback, is a setup, for a comeback.” - TD Jakes 

Nailing a 30-day meditation streak is nice.

With that said, it’s just as important to build up resilience and the ability to get back on track after we fall off.

To show ourselves that every misstep is an opportunity to change and come back into alignment.

This is true for meditation and really any meaningful habit we’re trying to develop. Working out, eating right etc.

Life is going to knock us around from time to time.

Remember that perfection is the enemy of progress. We don’t need to do everything, just something.

Tara Brach says “if you can’t sit for twenty-minutes today, sit for one.”

Whatever you need to do today…
Even if it’s only one minute…
Get after it.

You’re one step away from breaking the cycle.

P.S - Decembers challenge is a social media detox. Link to join is in my profile :)

First 360!

Not pretty, but it counts.

Next up, airs 🛩

Howdy friends - I wanted to update everyone on this months challenge.

This December we will be focusing on a 30-day social media detox.

Kick off call this Tuesday at 530pm cst. Link to join the group is in my link tree.

Detox does not mean no social media use at all - many of us need to post for work and it will essentially be about no unintentional social media usage or browsing. 

We’ll discuss strategies to set up our phone identity, resources to block social sites effectively and positive consequences that we can setup to help us stay accountable. We’ll also help people to find an “accountabilibuddy” to stay on track.

When I was thinking about what challenge to commit to for December, I thought about a few (diet, exercise etc).

When I considered giving up social media, I noticed a significant resistance to it.

That resistance is what made me realize that it is precisely what I should do.

As the stoics say “when we feel we can’t, we must.”

I hope this is a gateway to all of us finding deeper focus and energy for the things that truly deserve our attention.

Trying to be liked by everyone is the quickest way to a small life and shallow relationships.

Additionally, if we are performing or packaging ourselves, that’s not even the real us people are meeting. We aren’t actually being liked, our persona is being approved of. It might initially feel good on the surface, but this is not the foundation of an enduringly meaningful connection.

A thought that will guide us towards deeper authenticity is remembering that the goal is not to be liked by every person we meet. The goal is to like ourselves with every person we meet. 

The only way to find our people, is to bring the real version of ourselves forward in every conversation.

The Playground Study - an important lesson for hosts, organizers and meaningful experience design. 

Several years ago, a team of landscape architects conducted a simple study to observe the impact of having a fence around a playground, and how its consequent effects would impact preschool children.

By observing teachers and their students on a playground surrounded by a fence, and on a comparable playground with no fence, the researchers found an important difference in how the children interacted in the space.

On playgrounds without fences, the children tended to gather around the teacher, and were reluctant to stray far from their view. On playgrounds that were fenced in, however, they ran all around the entire playground, feeling more free to explore.

The researchers concluded that with a boundary, in this case a fence, children felt more at ease to explore the space.

I believe there is an interesting parallel with the physical constraints of a fenced-in playground, and the implied constraints that we put on social gatherings.

When people don’t know how to act, what to say or what is expected of them, they can often feel anxious and unsure of themselves.

As a facilitator, host or organizer, we can engineer confidence and meaningful connection by providing people with constraints. Examples include...

⁃ One conversation at the dinner table
⁃ Specific questions that we want people to ask
⁃ inviting folks to skip the small talk 
⁃ organized ice breakers

Just last night, the hosts of a networking event I went to led off by encouraging us to spend time with people we didn’t know. They asked us to resist the urge to spend time with those we already had a relationships with. 

After that, they started the night by gathering into four groups and working our way through four questions. What would you teach a class on if you had to? What is a secret spot you love in town? What was the highlight of your year? What are you most excited about 2023?

They took a stand for meaningful conversation from the jump. After the exercises, they invited us to carry this level of depth into the rest of our conversations.

The quality of our questions determines the quality of our life.

I was on The Coaching Podcast yesterday. One of the hosts asked me how I make men's work accessible to guys aren’t typically interested or available for it.

I explained that most men don't like to be told what to do. They want to figure it out for themselves.

That’s why I try to lead with curiosity.

On @wejunto retreats, our guys navigate a series of questions that help them to explore their masculine identity and better define the authentic self.

Each of these questions aligns with the four pillars of the Junto: Emotional mastery, Deconditioning, Identity, Contribution

1. Emotional mastery - what am I feeling and not sharing?

2. Deconditioning - what have I made it mean to be a man?

3. Identity - The authentic self
Values - Who am I? 

Purpose - Why am I here?

Legacy - What will I be remembered for? 

4. Contribution - What am I committed to that is bigger than me?

As much as our mind tries to identify strategic and tactical solutions to move our life forward, our sense of self and our beliefs about how the world works are the greatest determinant of our behavior and how we show up.

When we have deeper clarity around these questions, the fullness of life is more available to us.

Do you know your answers?

Austin, LA and NYC retreats now open on wejunto.com if you want to learn more.

Remember when you’d go over to a friends house as a kid and you wouldn’t say anything to them?

We would just walk in, start playing their Nintendo, raid the pantry, or turn on the TV without saying a word.

We weren’t going to do anything with them, we just wanted to be around them. We wanted to be in their presence.

I think there is an important lesson to be learned from this

Our best friends remind us of our essence. They remind us who we are.

Not with words, simply by being.

We feel they understand and accept us. They know we are good.

This knowledge puts us at ease, it makes us want to be around them…even when we’re not doing anything.

It’s fun to do stuff with friends.

But remember…

Savor those friends you can do nothing with.

—

If someone came to mind, share this with them.

Celebrate your friends the way you want to be celebrated.

Our men’s group gathered last night for one of my favorite rituals of the year, ”The End of Year Fuck Yeahs.”

Before our session, each man is invited to write down their answers to the following prompts:

- What did you achieve/accomplish that you’re most proud of?
- How did you grow as a person?
- How did you show up in ways that were new and important to you?

Before each person goes, we rally. We will start a slow clap or bang on a table to elevate the energy and get the group excited.

It can be hard to celebrate ourselves.

Humility is usually a virtue…not here.

Something powerful happens when we give people permission to go for it while sharing their big wins for the year.

They are more capable of seeing the awesomeness we see in them.

Also…it’s just more fun.

One by one, the men will stand up and go through their list. (We bring a speaker and microphone for added effect.)

When they say something important, the whole group let’s it rip…

FUCK YEAH.

Meaningful rituals don’t have to be serious, they can be silly and ridiculous.

End of year is a great excuse to unify your community around celebration.

Let it rip.

The fruit game.

Hand someone you love a piece of fruit and put them into a scene…

“There has been a cataclysmic event on planet earth.

All of the apples have suddenly died.

Inexplicably, all human knowledge about how to grow and cultivate apples has been forgotten. Humanity will never regain this knowledge.

Knowing that this is the last apple that will ever be consumed by you or anybody else, how would you eat it?

You can’t plant it’s seeds as it would now be useless.”

Give them a moment to enjoy their piece of fruit (in this case, a piece of green apple).

When they are done, regain their attention.

“Now, let me ask you a question. How is the apple any different than your life?

The fruit game is a fun way to help people remember that we only get one crack at this thing called life.

Are you savoring it?

Happy New Years y’all.

Holy shit, we’re alive.

The best way to start the day.

The gratitude meditation.

What are three things I’m grateful for.

What are three things I’m looking forward to?

if I don’t have time for gratitude, I know my priorities are off.

Take a moment for gratitude, magnify what’s right in the world.

The comfort of being disliked.

On New years eve, I hosted a party for around 70 people in Costa Rica.

It. Was. Awesome.

One of the moments that stuck out from the party was actually one of the suckiest.

I was very clear with attendees beforehand that we were full and not accepting additional invites or +1’s.  I asked our group to respect that and not ask me as it puts me in a tough position. 

Later that night, I was surprised to see three people I didn’t recognize.

I walked over, introduced myself and asked them how they ended up here. They told me that one of the women I specifically said no to, had invited them to the party.

I smiled and explained the situation.

“Hey, you seem like really nice people, but I specifically told XXX that we were full and that she could not invite anyone else.

It would be unfair to everyone else here if you were to stay. I hope you have a great night but you are unfortunately going to have to leave. Also, I really don’t want to ask again and am hoping that you can respect my decision and make your way out now.”

The three people looked surprised, but also like they could also tell that my mind was made up and I wanted them gone.

Within five minutes the scene was over and I went about my night.

Have you ever had that experience of being asked to include someone at a gathering that you don’t really want to invite?

There is pressure to add them and often worry that excluding them will lead to social repercussions or exclusion down the road?

In my younger days, the prospect of upsetting acquaintences was often too much for me and I would frequently abandon my own desires and boundaries to accommodate and include other people that I really didn’t want to.

In recent years, I weirdly look forward to these moments of discomfort.

Cont in comments…

“Close your eyes and think about what it felt like the moment you found each other.

Now, open to that feeling.”

New friends! @lordjonboy @th3duch3ss_

A counter intuitive approach to feeling great and getting shit done.

“We are all just doing what we’re doing because of how we think it will make us feel.”

When I have this amount of money, I’ll feel SAFE.
When I have a child, I’ll feel CONNECTED.
When I have those friends, I’ll feel LOVED.

Whether consciously or unconsciously, I believe this to be true.

It is natural to focus our attention on goals and what we want to achieve.

While that is an important aspect of achieving in the world, it misses a helpful piece.

It is also important to be clear on HOW WE WANT TO BE in the process.

When we focus on how we want to feel on the way to achieving our desired outcomes, the process becomes much more enjoyable and manageable.

So, ask yourself a question, “how do I want to feel today?”

Today I want to feel “focused, hopeful, courageous.”

Focus on three emotional states you’d like to occupy.

Simply by bringing your awareness to those emotional states, you make it more likely that you will feel that way.

When we put our attention on our intention, we’re more likely to create the experience we want.

Our behavior flows from whatever we give our energy and attention to.

“I create from joy”

This post is mainly for people who are fortunate enough to employ themselves or work at a job they enjoy. 

When I find myself feeling stressed, overwhelmed or frustrated with work, I say this to myself…

“I create from joy”

To me, it is a reminder that I chose this work.

A reminder that even the most mundane task is usually moving me closer to something meaningful.

A reminder that even if it’s not the most enjoyable thing to be doing, I am doing work that I picked.

That in and of itself is a gift that the vast majority do not get to experience. 

When I am aware of this gift, it’s easier to create from joy.

The work I create from joy is better.

More effective for my team.

More impactful on my community.

More enjoyable for me.

So, I choose to create from joy.

I make it part of my creative identity.

We all can.

The end of an era.

On September 1st, Miki and I decided to formally end our marriage.

That Thursday, we met at The Temple. The most sacred place at Burningman.

We chose this spot to honor our beginnings.

We married each other at the burn 11 years ago.  Before this dusty shotgun wedding, we had only hung out three times and came to the event explicitly as friends.

After meeting at the temple, we grabbed our bikes, locked hands and rode towards a wooden lifeguard stand in deep playa.

Before we spoke any words to each other, I asked to play a song for her, “Godspeed” by James Blake. (A Frank Ocean cover)

I listened to this song nearly every day during our separation. It conjured in me what felt like a “useful sadness.” Here are some of the final lyrics….

Wishing you godspeed, glory
There will be mountains you won't move
Still I'll always be there for you
How I do
I let go of my claim on you
It's a free world
You look down on where you came from sometimes
But still you'll have this place to call home always
Glory, glory, glory, glory

This love will keep us from blinding of the eyes
Silence in the ears, darkness of the mind 
This love will keep us from blinding of the eyes
Silence in the ears, darkness of the mind

—

As the tiny speaker filled the space, we looked into each others eyes and cried, both of us feeling into what was coming next.

After 11-years of life-changing partnership and a three month separation, both of us knew it was time to transition our relationship into one of loving co-parenting and friendship.

While the transition has been difficult at times, the overwhelming feeling I have is one of gratitude.

Gratitude that we still love one another. There is no shortage of love between us, there never has been. The constellation of our love has simply shifted from romantic love into that of familial love.

I’m grateful that our son Hiro will grow up in the presence of this deep love between us. 

I’m grateful that Miki is an amazing mother and one of the most inspiring people I’ve ever met.

I’m grateful for our incredible shared community who has showed up beautifully for us throughout the transition.

Continued in comments…

Have you ever had the of experience of getting completely lost in what you’re doing?

Your sense of self and time seem to disappear?

You’re fully present and your actions flowed naturally and without thought?

Maybe it was while dancing, playing sports, listening to music, creating art. It’s the best, right?

That’s “Flow,” a term coined by Mihai Csikszentmihalyi, who many cite as a co-founder of the positive psychology movement.

Simply said, a flow state is when you are feeling your best and performing your best. It is the peak state of human consciousness.

Researchers have been studying these peak states for the past thirty years and many academics agree on some of the core criteria, or “Flow Triggers” that need to be present for a flow state to occur. 

Here are some examples:

Trigger #1 - Intrinsic motivation: Doing something because you like the act itself, not for a specific outcome/result.

Trigger #2 - Presence/Focus: Focusing on what is happening right here, right now,. The inner dialogue goes away.

Trigger #3 - Control: We are focused on the things we can impact and forget the rest.

Trigger #4 - Clear goal: You are clear on what you want to accomplish, but you don’t focus on it.

—

For the last several years, I have been researching how we can create this type of flow with people and in every conversation.

I discovered something cool, simply by pointing our attention onto the right things, anyone can create Social Flow.

Drop a comment or DM me for the 4-question Social Flow framework for confident conversations and meaningful relationships.

Do you ever feel like you don’t know things that you should?

Like the people around you are smarter or capable than you?

If so, you’re not alone.

84% percent of entrepreneurs experience imposter syndrome. (@kajabi study)

—

This past week I was an event for entrepreneurs in British Colombia.

On the first night, I had a great conversation with someone high up at Andreessen Horowitz @a16z, one of the worlds top venture capital firms.

I asked “so, what is the differentiating quality that all of your most successful founders have in common?”

She responded with a simple answer…

“A growth mindset. They are the ones who learn most quickly and don’t allow anything to get in the way of their ability to learn new things.”

We talked about how so many entrepreneurs suffer from imposter syndrome and hurt their business because they are unwilling to seek help or ask questions the areas that they don’t feel like an expert in.

At the same event, I met someone who works with @raydalio from Bridgewater. Ray is respected as one of the best CEO’s out there and Bridgewater is know for having one of the most efficient, no-bullshit cultures around.

He backed up this idea and told me that one of the central values at Bridgewater is to not take feedback personally. By differentiating themselves from the work, they are more capable of receiving critical feedback that is necessary for making the best decisions and optimizing output.

He also said this is the thing that truly differentiated Ray, his ability to learn from any situation and put that information to use quickly.

—

Here’s a few ways we can embrace the growth mindset…

1. Accept that it is natural to feel insecure or like an impostor at times. If we are an entrepreneur/founder, we will constantly be doing things that are bigger and more complex than the work we did previously. Entrepreneurship is a journey of diving into what we don’t know and haven’t done before, over and over again.

Cont in comments…

If you want to write, speak, or teach, remember this…

“An idea is only as good as your audiences’ ability to implement it.”

This precisely why I spent so much time synthesizing Social Flow into a simple, four-question framework that we can use for confidence, conversation and meaningful connection wherever we go.

If you are interested in personal integrity and relational mastery, give it a whirl.

h/t @hilarycorna and unprofessional pod for the great convo!

“Mood follows action.”

A great line from buddy cowboy / Uber mensch @johnfitch.

A simple question to ask…

What’s the most important thing I can do today? 

Do that first.

Especially if it scares us or brings up significant resistance.

Everything else is a distraction.

Intention + Action = better mood.

Have a great week.

“I love you, because.”

In his best-selling book, “Influence”, Robert Cialdini  says “it is not our statement of affection that impacts the recipient, it is our explanation of it.“

Saying I love you is a beautiful sentiment, and…

It is actually our explanation of that sentiment that will have the deepest impact on the recipient.

So, if you love someone, tell them WHY.

I promise, our partners would much rather feel the depth of our appreciation, love and devotion than receive more stuff.

Happy Valentine’s Day.

A simple way to help people connect at your events.

Give people permission to do what they want to do anyways…

—

I opened up the @getgitcoin conference in Boulder last night.

Five minutes in to my talk on Social Flow, I looked out at a sea of raised hands.

Right before that, I invited the audience to consider that the strength of their community (and really any community or team for that matter) comes down to the strength of relationships within it.

And, all relationships start and grow the same way…with a single conversation.

Then, I asked the group a few questions.

“So, with the three days we have together...

Who wants to bypass the surface level chit chat and go deep?
 Who wants to skip the conversations about where we’re from and talk about who we are?

Who wants to talk about big ideas and what we need most right now?

Who wants to embrace the idea that life is too short for small talk.

Without even asking, the hands started to go up…until they were all raised.

I then invited the group to keep their hands up and take a look around.

You see that, that is your permission slip. 
A permission slip to be real and talk about things that matter while you’re here.

—

In today’s increasingly virtual world, our IRL time with coworkers and friends is few and far between, we need to make the most of it.

If you are leading gatherings, make it easier by giving your people permission.

Ask your audience up front what types of questions they want to ask and be asked.

Give people permission to be “full spectrum humans” where we can talk about what’s going well, and what’s challenging.

A little permission, goes a long way.

I spoke with a woman yesterday who told me a powerful story.

She let me know that her father had passed away suddenly last year.

She also told me that earlier in the year, she had given her father a Tribute.

She described her father as a very stoic man who she had never really seen cry…until he watched his Tribute. 

She went on to tell me how he would frequently revisit the Tribute over his final year. Some of her last memories with her father were watching the tribute together.

He got to leave this earth, knowing how much he mattered in the lives of the people around him.

—

If you’re waiting to share ALL of your gratitude for your parents, now is the time. You simply never know.

Let them know how much you and everyone care about them.

Mother’s Day and Father’s Day are right around the corner.

DM me and I will gladly send you a free code to create a @wetribute for them.

If everyone took care of their families, we’d have world peace “ - LZ

Last year I switched to a mostly keto diet and experienced a massive shift in my energy and emotional well being and confidence. 

For me, establishing a deeper relationship and discipline with my diet, made it easier to be more disciplined elsewhere in my life. 

if you’re curious, click the link for the healthy habit group in my profile. Free to join, I simply do this because it feels helpful for others and makes it more likely that I do it for myself.

—

Intermittent fasting is a dietary pattern that involves alternating periods of fasting and eating. There are different types of intermittent fasting, but the most common ones are:

Time-restricted feeding: This involves eating only during a specific window of time each day, typically 8-10 hours, and fasting for the remaining 14-16 hours.

Alternate day fasting: This involves alternating between days of normal eating and days of either no food or very restricted calories.

5:2 diet: This involves eating normally for five days of the week and restricting calories to 500-600 for the remaining two days.

Intermittent fasting has several potential benefits, including:

Weight loss: Intermittent fasting can help reduce calorie intake, which can lead to weight loss.

Improved insulin sensitivity: Intermittent fasting may help improve insulin sensitivity, which can lower the risk of type 2 diabetes.

Reduced inflammation: Intermittent fasting may help reduce inflammation in the body, which is a risk factor for many chronic diseases.

Improved heart health: Intermittent fasting may help improve several risk factors for heart disease, including blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and inflammation.

Increased longevity: Some animal studies suggest that intermittent fasting may help increase lifespan and reduce the risk of age-related diseases.

I had my first dinner in the new house last night with @thedanielaplattner. One thing we spoke about was our social media use and the nuance between sharing authentically vs. promoting.

For those who offer personal services (coaching/consulting/speaking etc.) you’ve probably felt this pressure to promote yourself in a way that generates leads or projects a certain image.

For me, I don’t think about social as promotional.

When it comes to instagram/Facebook specifically, I am following my internal mantra…

“I create art that reminds me how I want to live.”

I’m not “speaking” as though I want to be a thought leader, I simply aim to share my experience and what has proven valuable to me.

I consider this stream somewhat of a social journal.

A place that holds me accountable for articulating the lessons and experiences that have been useful in my life in a digestible way.

In the process of sharing publicly, I refine the wisdom of my life and make it easier to integrate those lessons and actually live them.

The point of wisdom, is to live it. Otherwise, it’s just an idea.

I take an autotelic approach. I try to enjoy the process itself.

When clients come though this channel, that is a bonus. Most importantly, I maintain my integrity, which is what I want for myself and anyone I work with.

Create art that reminds you how you want to live.

Anytime we feel tension, anxiety or resistance (T.A.R) in a social situation, it is likely because we are focused on external forces that we don’t control. 

Those externalities are usually things like, rejection, outcomes and perception (R.O.P). We are worried that well be rejected, won’t accomplish our goal, or be perceived negatively.

We will never control these externalities. We only control what we do, right now.

We can use the T.A.R we experience in social situations as a reminder to shift our attention internally, onto what we control. In Social Flow, we practice those as…

I - intentionality - How do I want to be? 
C - curiosity - What do I want to know? 
A - authenticity - What am I feeling and thinking?
N - now - How can I be more present?

Within this framework, The social anxiety we experience (and we all do) can be transformed into an opportunity to reclaim deeper states of freedom and integrity.

Thanks for having me @angelikaalana @awakenedlove

As Hiro put it…

The best advice I ever heard about how to have great sex, is just as relevant for how to feel confident and create meaningful conversation.

The advice is simple…

“Be less goal oriented.”

So often, we are doing things with our focus subconsciously on the outcome we want to achieve.

When we do this, we often miss out on the power and enjoyment available to us in the present moment.

Its most helpful to ask ourselves what we can do to make the process of connecting with people enjoyable… and follow that as our guide.

In the bedroom, or the boardroom.

On death.

My father passed away unexpectedly ten days ago.

I’ve spent the last week up here working through his affairs and figuring out just what one does after a parent dies.

The first few days felt like swimming in a rough ocean. Just when I felt like I had a grip on things, life would crash over me, leaving me overwhelmed.

After a week here, I am beginning to feel like I’m wading in calmer waters.

What makes the most sense now is simply to be here, fully present to the experience as it unfolds.

To welcome the emotions that are more difficult to decipher than usual.

To enjoy my finals days in his wonderfully weird home in the Alaskan wilderness.

To feel sad for the loss and then laugh at the cosmic joke…all in the same breath.

R.I.P Leslie J. Horn

Thank you.

I walked up to start my fathers eulogy and whispered into the mic…

What a task. How can you do justice to the life of any human in a speech? More so, your dad.

I don’t know that you can and I don’t know that I want to try…

So, I’ll just share a few of my favorite memories and the lessons that I want to carry forward in his honor:

I don’t know that we’re capable of appreciating our parents fully while they are here. So much of our own stuff gets in the way.

With that said, I tried. I was committed to create a loving, honest and deeply connected relationship with my dad…so I could have that type of relationship with my son.

On my first day in Alaska, I walked around his empty home and realized something. It’s impossible not to see that he had more photos on the walls than any person you’ve ever met. But somehow, I didn’t notice that he had covered every single wall in his home, floor to ceiling, with artwork.

Literally. every. wall.

Like most these days, I desire a more minimal aesthetic. Because of this, I don’t think I was able to fully appreciate the weird genius of his design choices… which I now lovingly refer to as maximalism to the max. There is simply no other house like it.

In a world where everyone is trying to tidy up and streamline their spaces, my dad was determined to fill every crevice of his home with items, things, and stuff that he loved.

It didn’t make sense to most people, not even me. But that didn’t matter…because it did to him.

He went for it.

This was true for all of his passions…

Flying experimental aircraft
Astrophysics and running observatories
Playing the double bass In orchestras
The list goes on…

He was relentless in the pursuit of his passions.

I’m grateful for this beautiful lesson.

And even more grateful that it didn’t come in the form of words.

But in witnessing how he lived.

From sitting quietly in a room, with a fire burning…

and thousands of pictures on the walls.

When I put my hand on the casket for the final time, I close my eyes and thought to myself…what do I want to remember from this moment?

What do I want to make of the last memory I will ever have in the presence my father’s physical body?

“Thank you”

I tapped the pine box several more times, repeating the phrase over and over again.

Let this memory be one of appreciation. 

Felt true for this moment, and I imagine it will be when it’s my time as well.

Thank you.

I bless the night that nourished my heart
To set the ghosts of longing free
Into the flow and figure of dream
That went to harvest from the dark
Bread for the hunger no one sees.

All that is eternal in me
Welcomes the wonder of this day,
The field of brightness it creates
Offering time for each thing
To arise and illuminate.

I place on the altar of dawn:
The quiet loyalty of breath,
The tent of thought where I shelter,
Waves of desire I am shore to
And all beauty drawn to the eye.

May my mind come alive today
To the invisible geography
That invites me to new frontiers,
To break the dead shell of yesterdays,
To risk being disturbed and changed.

May I have the courage today
To live the life that I would love,
To postpone my dream no longer
But do at last what I came here for
And waste my heart on fear no more.

By John O’Donohue

We often confuse stress and envy without realizing it…

Loved this nugget of wisdom from @officiallymcconaughey

“Stress is a word that has such a bad name right now, and I think it's getting a bad name kind of unfairly," he said. "Having a little bit of stress means you give a shit."

"We're labeling everything stress," he says, pointing to a child psychologist he's researched who interviewed children about what stresses them the most. "They were like, 'Well, I don't have as good of grades as Joe, I don't have the shoes that Jane has, I don't look as good as so and so' and he says, 'that's not stress, that's envy.'

As soon as he relabelled it envy for the child, the child was like, 'Oh, I can deal with that. I just didn't know how to deal with stress.'

—-

I have found distinction between stress and envy personally liberating and have also been using it with several of my coaching clients.

So, what’s the difference between stress and envy?

Simply said, stress is the experience of believing that we do not have the time, resources or skill to accomplish our goal(s).

Envy is a feeling of discontentment caused by someone else's success, possessions, or achievements.

Stress is based on us feeling we’re not able to do something we want to do.

Envy is based on the feeling we’re not able to do something someone else has done.

One is personal and the other is grounded in comparison.

It’s great to get inspired by other people and their accomplishments on the path…

But if we value happiness, it’s important to remember that comparing ourselves to others is a fools errand.

So next time we are stressed, ask if this goal is truly important for us and the people that depend on us?

Or, does it exist because we are comparing ourselves to someone else and what they have achieved?

If the latter, we know what to do.

Focus on our goals and remember that the only person we are truly competing with is ourselves.

That game is much more fun to play.

Anytime I help someone working through relational conflict, (at work or at home) I will frequently start with the same question…

“What are you feeling and not sharing”

It invites the person to move beyond their judgment or story of the other person (criticism) and plants them in their experience and feelings, which are much easier to share (constructive). 

So much of the tension that we carry in our bodies is the result of not having a difficult conversation. 

Feeling this tension is human. I encourage my clients to experience this this tension as an invitation to regain relational integrity and deeper connection in their relationships.

To me, relational integrity is when we have consciously expressed all of our meaningful feelings and thoughts towards someone.

If we’re not expressed, we’re not in integrity.

We don’t fully control the form our relationship takes, that takes two people.

We DO control our expression and commitment to integrity.

—-

They say “the truth shall set you free.”

That’s only half of it. 

I met a new friend recently. Within an hour of connecting, he shared something deeply vulnerable with me.

It was something he hasn’t spoken to many people about and I felt honored to hold it for him.

Our shame tries to convince us that sharing these “big secrets” will push people away.

In reality,  it often does the opposite. It builds trust and make people feel more connected to us.

This was also his girlfriends experience after he first shared it with her.

—

When we are withholding the truth.

We trap ourselves in a prison of our own creation.

Bars molded by the belief that we aren’t safe to be ourselves.

Walls built with the fear that we’ll be abandoned if people knew the real us.

We strip ourselves of the freedom to simply be who we are.

Remember this…

You re not alone. Everybody has their thing.

We all know the feeling of hiding something we feel people would just not understand or accept us for.

And more importantly…

When we hide our “big secret”, we are subconsciously modeling that everyone else needs to hide theirs too.

Do we want the people we love to feel like they need to hide the real version of themselves around us?

Do we want our friends or family members to live and maybe even die with their truth inside?

I certainly don’t.

I want to be a lighthouse for my friends authenticity and deepest truth.

That’s why I make a point to express those scary thoughts and share those big secrets.

To me, that’s the only way I can truly show my people that it is safe.

That’s why I relate to sharing these big secrets an act of service.

“The truth shall set you free.”

Is really…

“The truth shall set you free…and your people too.”

So, share the thing.

For yourself.

And also, the people you care about.

One of the most important things we can do to work through conflict is take ownership.

If someone has done something to hurt or annoy us, we want them to acknowledge what they did and the pain/frustration it caused.

On the other side, If we have hurt/annoyed someone we care about, offering them an “I’m sorry” is often one of the most effective ways to make them feel seen and understood.

One of the reasons this is so difficult to do, is because we often correlate apologizing or saying I’m sorry with “being wrong” or doing something “bad.”

If we feel that someone is trying to label us as a bad person for doing something, we go into defense mode, instead of owning.

The easier approach to taking ownership and helping others do the same, is to think about our own integrity.

Most of the time when we do or say something that impacts someone negatively, we were aren’t thinking clearly or perhaps we were in a triggered state.

Rather than thinking about whether or not what we did was the “right” or “appropriate”  thing, look back at what happened and ask this question…

“When I look back on what I said/did, is that the most effective way I could have acted in that moment?”

From our calm, grounded state we can evaluate the action and determine if it was or wasn’t in integrity with our highest self.

If it wasn’t, we can acknowledge what we did, share how it wasn’t aligned with what we wish we would have done or how we would have approached the situation and say sorry.

We don’t control what other people do, we DO control our ability to be in integrity with ourselves and take ownership when we miss the mark.

To me, that is a sign of true character and a quality I seek in all of my personal and professional relationships.

I had a great session with a client yesterday where we spoke about embracing the identity of “artist.”

He is a startup founder and shared how he appreciated his artist friends and the purpose they had in pursuing their craft.

He had trouble identifying with this label as his craft is more associated with creating great businesses…far outside the realm of traditional “fine art.”

I asked him if he knew what the literal definition of art is, he did not …

“Art is the Intentional arrangement of objects and things to engage the senses.”

In essence, it is the act of creating intentionally.

To me, our art is whatever we find intrinsically rewarding. The act of creating is meaningful regardless of the outcome.

If he was called to build beautiful systems for businesses to run efficiently and make people money…that is art to me.

When we are able to identify what “our art” is, we make purpose more accessible.

We find more joy and motivation in the process itself, instead of solely relying on outcomes.

When we are connected to this type of reverence for our craft, other people feel it too…it is captivating to be around a leader who has this type of passion and purpose.

Do you like books? 

Do you like your friends?

Do you like to party?

Well then, maybe you should consider hosting a Book Rave.

What’s a Book Rave you ask?

We’ll, it wasn’t a thing until this past weekend. 

I recently bought my first house in a town called Bee Cave, 20-minutes outside of Austin.

As soon as I moved in, I knew I wanted to create a custom built library and music room.

Also, I love throwing parties and wanted to host everybody before I went down to Costa Rica for the summer.

Enter: Book Rave.

I sent my friends an invite and told them I wanted to fill my new library with the wisdom that has shaped many of my favorite people. 

I also wanted to dance around my living room in funky clothes.

My friends were invited to show up to my house with a book or two that has been meaningful to them on their journey.

When they got to the house, I played fun music and encouraged everyone to skip the small talk in favor of asking people what books they brought and why they chose them.

With a simple prompt, the conversations shifted towards depth, wisdom, ideas and stories about peoples’ personal transformations.

It was fantastic.

Whether it’s a Book Rave, or a team building workshop for your company, I believe the best hosts embody the role of “conversation catalyst.”

A conversation catalyst is someone who makes it easier for a group of people to have meaningful conversations.

And…

I believe meaningful conversations are the quickest path to building meaningful relationships.

What book would you have brought me?

The other day I was driving to my men's group and feeling real good.

I just closed another coaching client and was enjoying the clarity that this will likely be my most successful year yet.

As we begun our group session, I noticed my joy turning into a pit into my stomach.

What the feck is going on? I thought.

I quickly realized that I was comparing myself to several of the “hyper-successful” men in the group.

Thoughts like "You're doing well, but not nearly as much as them. You'll never reach their level" crept in.

Fortunately, I know this thought loop well and have distilled a simple 4-step process to respond consciously when we compare ourselves to others.

Step 1: Awareness: Recognize that comparison is natural. We all do it at times—it's part of being human.  This sounds like… “I am comparing myself to x.”

Step 2: Identify the story: Are there limiting beliefs fueling this comparison? ? I.e. “I will never be that wealthy. I will never be as confident as y.”

Step 3: Dismantle the limiting belief: Apply @byronkatie's transformative 4-question process called "The Work." Google it—it's a game-changer.

Step 4: Celebrate: Shift your focus from envy onto admiration. They are simply showing you something you want for yourself. i.e. “I am so inspired by what she has accomplished. I love how confident he is in conversation”

When we compare, we tend to push people away. When we appreciate, we often feel more connected.

Step 5: Take action: Choose one thing you can do today to cultivate the qualities or achievements you admire. Start small and commit to progress.

By following these steps, you transform comparison from a negative spiral into a generative thought that propels you toward your goals.

Do you love bike rides?

Do you love your friends? 

Do you like going on adventures?

Perhaps you should start your own “Bikey gang”

What is “Bikey gang” you ask?

Well, it was not a thing until this past weekend.

I wanted to do something fun for friends who were in from out of town and was inspired by the epic Cyclones rides that @jesseisrael used to do in NYC and LA.

Here’s a breakdown of how to plan an epic “Bikey Gang” adventure in your city with minimal effort and pretty much no cost…

1. Get all your friends to meet at a local bike shop.  Call them ahead of time to let them know you are bringing a big group so it goes quickly. 

2. Ask several of your friends to bring portable speakers they can strap to their bikes. 

3. Start a collaborative listening session on Spotify and invite up to 6 folks to join you. The playlist will sync and play through all the speakers at the same time…now you are in business. (Use one of my “road to Burningman playlists for maximum vibe)

4. We charted a trail around Lake Austin so we didn’t have to deal with traffic, highly recommend. Plan a few stopping spots ahead of time for water breaks / spontaneous dance parties. 

5. For lunch, start a group order on uber eats and set it so that everyone pays for their own lunch. Stop off in a park or public place where you can chill out and play sports…thanks to @millbrookatx for hosting us for some pickle ball. 

6. To take it all home, head somewhere wet to cool down after a long day of physical activity. A lake, pool or wherever you can properly chill out. We went paddle boarding on the lake and capped it off w/ a dip in @bartonsprings pool. 

That’s it, welcome to the Bikey gang. 

We’re going to run this back in Austin this fall, holler if you want to join 🤠

Next time you feel self-conscious around people, remember this…

It is very hard to experience fear and curiosity at the same time.

Fear usually manifests in the body as T.A.R (tension, anxiety and resistance).

T.A.R. Usually arises because we are subconsciously afraid of being judged. That shows up in our subconscious internal dialogue as…

“These people don’t like me”
“These people don’t care about me”

To pattern interrupt the fear, introduce curiosity.

What do you want to do know about these people? What are they most excited about? What’s important to them right now? 

List as many questions as you can and watch a lightness wash over your body.

You have just transitioned from self-consciousness to other-consciousness.

From this place of curiosity, confidence and connection will flow much more naturally.

So remember…

It’s very hard to feel fear and curiosity at the same time.

Choose wisely.

Have you ever had a conversation with someone where you felt like you were just missing each other?

You don’t feel understood, heard, or like your words are  being manipulated?

Next time, ask this question. Are we focused on content, or context?

Great Relational Leaders spend the majority of their time on the latter.

So, what is content? 

It is the what. What was said, what we experienced, what we needed.

And, what is context?

It is the why and the how.  It’s the invisible thread that weaves meaning into our conversations. It’s setting a clear conversational purpose, values and expectations for how we want to have the conversation.

Often times we miss each other in conversation because we do not have a shared context for how we want to have the conversation.

Context creates safety and unlocks the rich tapestry of insights, experiences, and perspectives that make meaningful dialogue possible.

Relational leadership isn’t just about sharing information; it’s about fostering understanding and connection.

Setting context is one of the most powerful ways to do this.

H/t to @consciousleadershipgroup for so many great insights in this arena!

Conscious conflict 🧠

What is your relationship with conflict?

While most of us intellectually understand it as a valuable tool for connection, our reaction frequently tells a different story.

When we feel tension with someone, our first instinct is often to judge others, distract ourselves or disengage all together.

We can shift with a simple re-frame…

Here is my personal definition of conflict that helps me to respond consciously when things get tense…

Conflict is energy. (shoutout @jaydigges for the concept). Conflict is a valuable opportunity to cultivate deeper understanding, connection and progress in my life. It is the most important place to amplify my own personal growth.

When I feel tension with someone, various affirmation also help me to respond consciously:

“There is important information here.”

“This is an opportunity to understand this person more deeply.”

“We will be stronger after resolving this.”

After this, a simple way to transform conflict into conscious conflict is another C word…Curiosity. 

“I wonder what they are feeling or what they needed?”

“What am I feeling? What did I need? What do I want moving forward?”

So much conflict exist because our curiosity simply hasn’t been expressed. 

Start there to shift into conscious conflict.

Loved joining @scottbrit on the EvolutionFM podcast to talk about Relational Leadership and conscious communication.

What is Relational Leadership?

It is based on the central belief that building strong relationship is the most rewarding path for effective leadership and living a fulfilling life.

Relational leaders take full responsibility for the quality of their relationships. Be that a co-worker, spouse, or family member. They understand that cultivating healthy relationships is the force multiplier for their own growth and impact. 

To help my clients master Relational Leadership, we focus on four core skills that I call “The 4 C’s” 

Confidence - I define confidence as respecting ourselves and telling the truth. I help leaders to step into deep integrity with themselves so they feel good and earn the respect of others by being authentic and telling the truth.

Conflict resolution - Conflict is one of the most valuable tools we have for cultivating deeper understanding and connection in our relationships. I help leaders to embrace conflict as a source of energy and meaningful action.

Collaboration - This is all about creating the context where creativity, innovation and solution-centered thinking thrive.

Clear communication - This is how we cultivate influence and inspire others to action. I help leaders to articulate the value of their ideas so that they can garner buy-in and be understood when it matters most.

This is the foundation of my approach to exucutive life coaching and it is the synthesis of ten years of studying interpersonal dynamics, texting strategic communication and leadership coaching.

If you’re looking for a coach to help you take this part of your life and leadership to the next level, let’s chat.

I recently watched my first sunset. Literally.

I planned a day for me and 11 friends to close out my trip in Nosara. As the sun came down, it began to shine directly on us and I asked my partner if she wanted to move.

She looked back at me and said, “no way, this is the best sun of the day.”

As I looked back at her, I noticed that she was looking directly at the sun. I could see it reflecting in her eyes.

Surprised, I asked her why she was staring directly at the sun.

She responded with a confused grin, “looking at the sun early and late in the day is one of the best things we can do for our health.”

I responded, “well, not right at the sun, right?”

“So long as it doesn’t hurt or strain your eyes, it is really good for you.”

I honestly didn’t believe her at first, I asked several of the people around us, who I consider smart, health informed people and they agreed that it is safe at sunrise and sunset.

My lifelong belief “don’t look directly at the sun,” was being shown to be false. The advice I heeded to keep me healthy was doing the exact opposite.

Whoa. 

Have I been doing sunsets wrong this whole time? What have I been missing?

I walked up the stairs to @gunnarlovelace’s beautiful yoga deck and watched the sun slowly disappear behind the pacific.

As I looked directly into the sun for the first time, I announced to the group, “team! this is the first time I have actually watched the sunset!”

Gunnar chimes in, “us humans are so self centered, the sun isn’t setting. The sun is stationary, the earth is turning and falling away from it.”

I chuckled and realized that my first sunset wasn’t really a sunset at all, it was an earthset.

As the day came to a close I couldn’t help but think about the famous Anais Nin quote…

“We do not see the world as it is, we see it as we are.”

Our beliefs are powerful. They can work for us and they can also work against us.

We would be wise to inspect them, evolve them and most importantly, choose them consciously.

H/t: @hubermanlab for the amazing podcast on the health benefits of sun exposure and how to do it effectively.

When is the last time you did a weekend without your phone?

This is one of the final messages I send to our men the week before a @wejunto retreat.

—

An important invitation…

One of the core objectives of this weekend is to simply feel and express our feelings fully. This simple action is one of the fundamental steps in reclaiming a deeper sense of personal integrity and relational mastery in our lives.

There is a reason that few of us take the time to feel our feelings fully, it can be an uncomfortable experience. We often don’t know what to do with all that emotion.

When we don’t know what to do, it is very human to distract ourselves and avoid this discomfort. Everything from stress to boredom.

The phone was engineered to provide the opposite experience. A consistent dopamine drip with every pickup.

As we give into this urge, we shrink our capacity to simply be with our experience, notice what is arising and feel into what is real. We make our default human experience less stimulating and biologically desensitize our dopamine receptors. 

As we get closer to Friday, I wanted to extend an invitation to digital detox from your phone.

Set an away message on your email and customize your text away message on your phone to let people know you are digital detoxing at a retreat and they can call me if anything urgent comes up. I will have my phone on me at all times.

Every man who has committed to this action on previous Junto retreats has said it contributed significantly to their experience over the weekend.

If you feel resistance to this invitation, I would encourage you to get curious about that resistance?

- What is my resistance to not being on my phone? 
- What can I absolutely not miss from Friday afternoon to Sunday afternoon? 
- What is my relationship with my phone and distraction in general?
- Who would I be if I didn’t use the phone to distract myself from being fully present?

That last one always get me, who would I be if I allowed myself to be fully present.

The closer I get to the answer, the better life gets.

Please drop a like on this post if you plan to join me this weekend and feel free to ask any logistical questions.

One of my favorite quotes from my epic conversation with @itsandrewhorn. This principle has been front and center for me the last few months.

You can't control how others perceive you. 

You can't control another person's experience of you.

Nor do I want to. 

The only thing that feels deeply nourishing to me at this point in my life is maintaining the relationship I keep with the man in the mirror. 

Did I honor him in this conversation? Did I make him proud with this interaction? Did I show up in ways that are in harmony with his values? 

If yes - I double down. 

If not - I learn, reflect, and course correct. 

If you are living a life of growth and authenticity, you will bump up against your edges. 

Especially with your relationships. 

You will be gifted with interactions that serve as opportunities to refine your sense of self.  

So instead of trying to be liked by everyone, strive to be in integrity with who and what you are. 

Allow vulnerability and intimacy to exist. 

Doing so gives the people you are interacting with the permission to do the same 💛

If you’re interested in hearing a deep dive on this principle, listen to the full Stay Grounded episode on Youtube or all of the podcast apps.

“Shame dies in sunlight”

A couple of years ago, I sat at a dinner table with @estherperel and asked her for a hot take on modern men’s work.

“What is the biggest issue you think all these practitioners and organizations should be trying to address?”

She responded with one word…

“Shame”

She went on to share her perspective that the unexpressed shame men hold is one of the primary causes for much of the pain that men experience and project into others. I agree with her.

When it comes to shame, there are a few important things I have learned.

1. Everyone feels shame. Feeling shame is part of life. This simple reminder makes it so much easier to acknowledge, confront and integrate our shame. 

2. Shame dies in sunlight and thrives in secrecy. When we share our shame with others, it is much easier to acknowledge it for what it is…a story and not some deep, dark truth about who we are.

3. When we embrace the vulnerability of sharing our shame, we increase our capacity to hold space for other people. We make it easier for others to be the full, authentic version of themselves because they feel like they can trust us.

4. It is helpful to distinguish between shame and guilt. Guilt sound like “I have done something bad (behavior),” where as shame usually sounds like “I am fundamentally bad (self).” Esther has a great quote about this as well…

“The shift from shame to guilt is crucial. Shame is a state of of self-absorption, while guilt is an emphatic, relational response, inspired by the hurt you have caused another.”

5. It is important to consider discernment when sharing shame. Just because we are feeling something, does not mean we should become a firehose of emotion. If we have hidden shame, start by finding someone you trust to see you and hold your story in confidentiality. If you don’t have someone like that, there are trained therapists and coaches out there to hold this space. Reaching out for help is a sign of strength, not weakness.

H/T @raj_jana for the great conversation.

One year ago today, my life changed for the better.

I had just finished giving a talk at the Playa Alchemist pyramid at Burningman. After the talk, I decided it was time to go.

I walked to my e-bike, unlocked it, turned it on and started to ride away.

But then, I heard a voice in my head. It didn’t sound like my own…

“Don’t go.”

I decided to listen. I locked my bike and walked back into the lounge area.

I proceeded to look around the room, making eye contact with strangers and then…I saw a beautiful woman sitting on the floor. Her head was turned away from me.

“What is that!?” I thought.

After a minute, she turned around and smiled. I walked over, sat in front of her and our eyes met. Holding eye contact was effortless here. As we started to talk, the voice in my head came in loud and clear…

“You don’t need to try here. She wants whatever you are.”

I felt my whole body relax in that moment. It felt like home. What has emerged over the past year has been nothing short of magic.

From Joshua tree to Sedona, surfing in Costa Rica, battleship and playing tricks with Hiro, hot tub time machines, building our home in Austin, meeting the families, ACL, ceremony bangers and back to Burningman again.

I love you with all my heart.

You are deeply kind, fully embodied and one of the most passionate souls I have ever met.

I love how you communicate, I love how hard working you are, I love how present you are, I love how voraciously curious you are, I love how devoted you are to your music and spiritual path, I love how you take care of your body and health, I love how you show up for your friends, family and Hiro.

I am more me with you and I am so grateful for the opportunity to build a life with you.

Thank you for loving me the way you do. It is the greatest gift and I simply can’t get enough.

As you always say…

“Show me how it gets better than this.”

We are just getting started.

“Did you ever wonder why I didn’t say I love you?”

The week after Melissa and I met at Burningman, I planned a trip for us to Joshua Tree. In the middle of a hike through Jumbo Rocks campground, we paused to hug each other. What happened next was one of the most powerful experiences of my entire life. 

We stopped in a clearing next to a hundred towers of stacked stones. We hugged each other tightly as the cool breeze flowed over our skin.  As I held her head on my shoulder, we began to weep for the next 10 minutes straight.

It’s hard to find words to do this moment justice. It felt like my soul had met a wandering piece of itself. I knew that I was completely and utterly safe to be there, fully present. It felt like home.

Later that night, I went home and googled “what is a twin flame?”

In that moment, I knew that I loved Melissa. I was also certain that she loved me too.

I could have said “I love you,” everything in me wanted to.

But then, I had an idea…

While saying it would be powerful, a new opportunity emerged in this unspoken certainty.

What if I decided to transcend words and find other ways to express my love for her? What would it feel like to channel the love I wanted her to feel through my gaze, my embrace and pure presence.

I decided that I would wait one year to tell Melissa I loved her.

I would use this year to anchor into the energy of love without words.

In all those moments that I wanted to say it over the last year (and there were many), I would simply slow down…

I would look deeply into her eyes.
I would hold her her tighter, longer. 
I would send her the loving energy I felt in my body.

I’m so grateful I waited.

Yesterday was the first day I told Melissa I loved her. As it turns out, I was right. Melissa knew she loved me in that clearing too.

While it has been so powerful to say the words these last few days, there is something much deeper available to us now.

It is in the little moments we share.
It is louder in the silence.
It is felt through the stillness in our bodies.

It’s as true as anything I’ve ever known.

“That was one of the most meaningful experiences of my life…”

- Boaz (Junto #13)

So, what is it about a Junto retreat that consistently creates this type experience for men?

Fundamentally, I believe it is because we help men to answer a question that few people ever really answer….

“How would the people in my life respond if they knew the real me?”

What I’m really feeling.
What I’ve been holding onto and not sharing.
Where I’ve been out of integrity.

So many of us hold unconscious beliefs that the people around us can’t handle, or simply don’t want the real, raw, unedited version of us.

So, we hide.

We suppress our feelings instead of expressing them.

We judge others and criticize instead of sharing what we need.

We disengage when relationships get uncomfortable or hard.

We package ourselves and present the version we think people want.

At the Junto, we create space for men to take full responsibility for their relationships and lives. To push beyond the stories and get in touch with reality.

To do this, we train men how to…

- Feel our feelings fully
- Share our experience consciously
- Take responsibility in asking for what we want
- Create space for others to be authentic too

Time and time again, men see that when we are willing to let go of the idea of who we think we need to be and show up as we really are, people respond positively…

They trust us more because they can feel we are telling the truth.

They respect us more because they can see us doing a hard thing with intention.

They are grateful because we’ve made it easier for them to share the things they have been holding on to.

Once we have experienced ourselves living and communicating from this place of truth, there is no going back.

It becomes harder to accept anything less from ourselves and the people around us.

In healing our relationship to others, we reclaim our integrity and transform what is possible for our lives.

—

Setting The Frame - A 30-second trick to feel more energized and confident at large social gatherings.

On Saturday night, I went to the @wearehfc that my friend @manishmas was co-hosting.

When I was younger, events like this could be very draining for me. Exciting and rewarding, but also stressful. I’d put pressure on myself to meet new people and often fell into the trap of performing or telling myself I needed to be a certain way.

I’ve built up a collection of pragmatic tools to show up naturally and confidently in these types of rooms and last night I did something fun that plays on a deeper idea.

I call it “setting the frame.”

Whether we are aware of it or not, our mind is setting the frame.

Setting the frame is the largely unconscious process of predicting how the events we participate in will turn out. The mind will naturally assume things like…

- Whether it is going to be fun
- whether there are going to be people there you will connect with
-  whether it will require a lot of effort

Where our story goes, energy flows.

If we have a limiting story like, “this will require effort” or “this might be draining” we are more likely to feel these ways in the process because we’re looking for that to be true. The mind craves certainty.

When we set our frame consciously, we can choose a story that directs our energy where we would like it to go.

For me, I sat in my Uber and said to myself. “You are going to meet someone here that is going to play a very significant role in your life.“

Believing that story engineered a level of intrigue, presence and curiosity that felt good in my body…so I went with it.

After you have the frame, you can micro-meditate into the future state where that story has come true. Often, you’ll notice the positive feelings of that imagined future state arising in the present moment…it’s surprising and sneakily powerful.

At the end of the night, I spent some great time with friends, met some cool new people, but alas… I didn’t think I had met someone new who would obviously be a big part of my life.

Here’s the fun part, it doesn’t matter.

Building on my post yesterday about “setting the frame.”

I view this as one of the biggest opportunities in parenting.

While our kids are young and malleable, they are developing their understanding of the world and how it works.

This includes their beliefs about who they are and how people perceive them.

Our sense of self if the greatest determinant of our behavior.

I was having a conversation with master coach @bryan_franklin one day, and I asked him for a piece of advice he would pass on to new parents.

He shared a practice that he had explored while raising his son. He consciously attempted to gift his son with four or five beliefs that he felt would most empower him. He repeated these beliefs over and over again.

One that stuck with me was…

“Anyone who meets me can love me.”

I asked myself a question, what beliefs do I wish I could have adopted when I was 4? 

Ever since that conversation, I amended my nighttime ritual with hiro to close with the same statements.

I am loved.
I am supported.
I am perfect exactly as I am.
I am safe.

I think am better for choosing to believe these things, I hope he is too.

How to hold boundaries with  unconditional love.

“Our capacity to love someone else correlates directly to our capacity to love ourselves.” I think @timferriss said this.

In relationship, I believe self love is tangibly expressed by knowing, respecting snd enforcing our boundaries.

A disagreement I had with miki this summer significantly shifted how I think about, speak to and hold my boundaries.

Miki had broken an agreement and hurt my feelings. Goes without saying that I have broken agreements and hurt her in the past as well. Instead of the normal, non violent communication style expression of my needs…

 I said…

I love you.
Nothing you can do will ever make me consciously stop loving you.
When you do ________ it makes it a lot harder for me to love you.

When someone hurts us, the instinctive reaction is often to withdraw our love and affection.

We instinctively feel if we remove our love and cause them pain, our partner will be more likely to shift the undesired behavior.

I don’t want to stop loving because someone has hurt me.

I want to keep loving when it gets hard…

AND

Show people the objective things they do that make it harder to love them.

I want to inspire my partner, friends and family  to inspect their behavior from love, not from fear or inflicting pain.

Do less, connect more.

This past weekend, I was invited to open up a three day festival in Miami with a Social Flow workshop. 

I told my friend @justinpmcleod that I was doing it and he jokingly said…

“So everyone is just gonna walk around and eye gaze with each other?”

He made me think about something that many of us, me included often feel when we think of “connection exercises” at work or other events.

While we grasp the value of them, we subconsciously feel like it is going to require real effort, or that we’ll need to force it in some way.

I created the Social Flow framework to show people that the opposite can be true.

That the most confident and connected version of ourselves likely exists with LESS effort.

Less trying to package ourselves.
LeSS guessing how people will perceive us.
Less trying to control the outcome.

Less doing, more being.

Simply accepting ourselves exactly as we are 
Asking the questions that we really want to ask 
Creating the conversations, we are naturally energized to be in 

Social flow provides a practical four question framework to do just that … I.C.A.N.

I - intentionality - How do I want to be? 
C - curiosity - What do I want to know? 
A - authenticity - what am I feeling OR What do I want to talk about ?
N - now - Can I be more present?

Thanks to brilliant meditation  teacher @emilystellafletcher who inspired this frame.

At the beginning of one of her talks, she spoke to resistance that many of us feel when we think about meditating. That it is something we have to DO and TRY at. She brilliantly remarked that meditation is more of a practice in doing less. That idea made it easier for me to commit to the practice.

At the end of the day, the greatest conversations are just a relational meditation. Simply being present with ourselves and another, and being honest with what comes up.

Eclipse camp out. Play for the sake of play.

What is play? 

Stuart Brown wrote a book on it - he says “ The truth is that play seems to be one of the most advanced methods nature has invented to allow a complex brain to create itself.”

Here are the 7 properties of play…

1. PURPOSELESSNESS
Or rather, apparent purposelessness, as Brown refers to it. Apparent purposelessness reflects the absence of practical value in the activity. It may not necessarily earn money or bring about material advantages.

2. VOLUNTARY NATURE
Play has no obligatory aspect. It does not force us to take part through duty or external requirements. In fact, through obligation, the activity loses its play component.

3. INHERENT ATTRACTION
Play is fun, and it makes us feel good. From a behavioural science perspective, it is said to bring about psychological arousal. In other words, it gets us excited and is a cure for boredom.

4. FREEDOM FROM TIME
When we are playing we lose track of time. It is freedom in its truest sense and provides an escape from the constrained world of demands and commitments.

5. DIMINISHED SELF-CONSCIOUSNESS
When we are playing, we drop the need to look good. There's no concern for what others think of us. There's no thought about thought and we become lost in the activity. It's what Maslow referred to as peak experience, and what Csikszentmihalyi called flow.

6. IMPROVATIONAL POTENTIAL
Another aspect of play, according to Stuart Brown, is that it has improvisational potential. There is no specific system of doing things. Instead, we are open to serendipity and chance occurrences that can lead to creativity and the discovery of new things.

7. CONTINUATION OF DESIRE
In play, we desire its continuation and will invent new means to make it last. It is the pleasure of the experience that drives the desire, and from this, we make new rules so the game need not end.

“Authenticity is not a virtue”

This is Jhakeem from Junto #13.

I spend a lot of time helping leaders to connect with their emotions. One important distinction I make upfront is this…

Authenticity is not a virtue.

Authenticity with positive intent is.

Just because we are feeling or thinking, something does not mean that we should say it.

This is the practice of discernment.

Be clear on why our authenticity is meaningful or helpful and it will be easier to discern what deserves to be shared.

Notice I used the words meaningful and helpful there.

Sometimes meaningful shares can be uncomfortable or even painful for someone to receive. Great leaders embrace this reality.

They know that authenticity with positive intent creates space for others to express themselves and be candid too.

They know that telling the truth is the most efficient path to building trust.

Do you have a relationship in your life that feels off?

Have you fallen out with an old friend or colleague that you used to be close with?

Have you completely lost touch with someone after a significant fight or period of conflict?

If so, this could help.

One of the primary tools within Gestalt Awareness Practice is something called “unfinished business.” It is a practice used to deepen awareness of our experience by addressing the things in our relationships that have been left unsaid.

I created the Unfinished Business Framework to make it easier for people to transform their “unfinished business” into clear and compassionate communication deepens connection and restores integrity.

The conversations we’re avoiding are some of our biggest opportunities for growth.

Lean in.

A 3-step process to address the hidden force behind social media addiction.

I recently had a bit of a relapse into unconscious social media scrolling. With the news of war and pressure to stay informed, I saw that many other friends were experiencing the same.

As I started to course correct, I noticed an important and often neglected force that contributes to social media addiction. Shame.

That sounds like the voice in your head saying “I’m lazy or addicted to social media.”

 Here’s a three-step process to notice it, interrupt it and replace it with the desired behavior.

According to the identity model of change, our sense of self is the greatest driver of our behavior. We will do the things that align with who we think we are.

If we are unconsciously telling ourselves that we’re lazy, we’re more likely to act lazy. 

If we are unconsciously telling ourselves that we are addicted to social media, we are more than likely to give to our social media compulsions.

1. Identify the shame story

“I am lazy/weak because I am so addicted to social media.”

When we use social media compulsively, we often tell ourselves a negative story about who we are without even realizing it. This is reinforcing a disempowered sense of self that will make it more likely that we repeat the undesired behavior. 

2. Shift the shame into guilt 

“When I use social media unconsciously, it is evidence of my laziness/weakness.”

The story we tell ourselves matters. Shift from a hyperbolic assessment of self (who I am), to a specific statement about the behavior (what I did) to avoid the disempowering identity trap.

3. Create evidence for the empowering story. 

“When I respond consciously to my social media compulsion, it is evidence of my growth and power to change.”

When we make good decisions, turn it into evidence or proof of an empowering story. When we reaffirm our empowered identity, we’re more likely to repeat the desired behavior.

"Comparison is the thief of joy."

A reminder to focus inward for growth, rather than outward for validation.

It's easy to fall into the trap of comparing our behind-the-scenes to someone else's highlight reel.

Joy comes from knowing our effort is sincere, our path is authentic, and our victories, no matter how small, matter.

Don't let the cycle of unconscious comparison steal that joy.

Appreciate the journey, embrace our own pace, and find gratitude for all that we have and what we’ve already accomplished.

We overestimate what we can do in a week, and drastically underestimate what we can do in a year.

What is the secret to effective conflict resolution?

@jaysongaddis has spent more than 20 years trying to answer this question.

He is the Founder of @therelationshipschool and his WSJ bestselling book “Getting to Zero” provides a practical framework to master conflict resolution in our important relationships.

I recently had him on “What’s the Big Idea” and he offered up a ton of practical wisdom about how we can approach conflict consciously, tips for effective communication, and how to navigate the inner turmoil that challenges our personal fulfillment and growth.

Here are 4 key takeaways from our chat…

1. Taking ownership: Jayson explained how approaching conflict with ‘ownership’ of our actions is key to constructive outcomes. This involves stepping out of the victim mentality and acknowledging one’s contribution to the situation, even when we think the other person is at fault. 

2. Cognitive Empathy versus Feeling Felt: He shed light on the distinction between understanding someone’s feelings (cognitive empathy) and truly making them feel understood, emphasizing the latter’s powerful impact in conflict resolution. 

3. Inner Conflict Resolution: Jayson discussed the concept of inner conflict derived from compromising our true selves for acceptance. He also provides practical outlets and practices to bring harmony to the inner and outer worlds.

4. LUFU - LUFU means that you make a commitment to Listen to the other person Until they Feel Understood. It is a simple way to sharpen your listening skills in high impact conversations. 

If these snippets piqued your interest, tune into the episode for deeper insights and tips.

You’ll walk away from this chat with a new lens to embrace difficult conversations and face conflict as an opportunity to grow in your important relationships. 

Enjoy.
