The wisdom of resistance.

I just finished a weekend in the woods with the men of @wejunto cohort #14.

In the midst of a powerful moment from the weekend, I was confronted with an important insight about RESISTANCE.

A man was exploring some of the challenging emotions he was holding in relationship to his father.

I invited him to breathe into these emotions.

Each breath welcoming them in more deeply.

I invited him to consider that he didn’t need to change or solve these emotions.

I invited the man to simply notice what he was experiencing and welcome them in fully.

As he dove into his internal world, I sensed a tension arising in him…and in me.

When we experience tension in our bodies, it is usually because we are in a state of resistance.

When we are feeling peaceful in our bodies, it’s usually because we are in a state of trust.

 I invited him to consider something else…

Do you notice any resistance to feeling these emotions?

“Yes, I feel it in my shoulders and in my head.”

I’d like to invite you to welcome those feelings in as well.

What does it feel like to welcome the resistance and those emotions at the same time?

The man’s spine erected, he took a deep breath.

In welcoming the resistance, the challenging emotions were more accessible to him. He spoke to them with a newfound clarity and precision.

“I must do for him what he could not do for me.”

I felt shivers run down my spine when he said those words. Deep, undeniable truth.

After the man concluded his process, I reminded our group of something. 

If we want to feel our feelings fully, we must welcome the resistance to feeling as well.

Much of the tension and reactivity we experience in our body, is not actually emotion…

It is the resistance to feeling emotion.

When we find ourselves in a state of reactivity, it helps to ask ourselves a few questions:

1. What is the emotion that I am feeling?
2. Is there a thought or story attached to that emotion?

And finally…

3. Am I experiencing resistance to feeling this emotion? 
4. If so, can I welcome in the resistance AND the emotion fully?

There is great wisdom in resistance. 

Feel it.

Free yourself.

Happy Thanksgiving! 

While we can certainly be grateful for experiences, places and things… I like to remind my team @wetribute that our gratitude for people is most important.

Today, let’s make it a point to share our gratitude with the people we’re with.

Here’s an invitation to reach out to four specific people in your life with a gratitude message today.

Let’s tell them why we appreciate them.

Let’s tell them why they’re awesome.

When we share appreciation with people, everything changes.

In an instant, they know they matter. That they have had an impact.

You also make it easier for them to share their gratitude with you.

Here’s a gratitude practice you can put into place on this special day…

When you have some time after Thanksgiving dinner, make a list of your friends. Then, take 15 minutes to share a voice note with each of them. Simply let them know what they mean to you.

Today, let’s be grateful for people.

And always remember…

If you have anything nice to say, say it all.

Why you should let your friends watch…

…you argue.

A few weeks back, Melissa and I were talking through a sensitive issue in our relationship.

We call these conversations “tendies” because they are…tender. She gets full credit for this one. 

We were having some difficulty coming to a resolution that felt good for both of us. After some prolonged friction, Melissa suggested something.

“would you be open to hanging out with @emmybush and @baya_voce and talking through this with them?”

I love these two and trust them, so I immediately said yes.

When we got to their house, we had a casual dinner, and then the energy naturally shifted to our challenging conversation.

We started just as we had before, me and Mel going back and forth, but it was different this time. 

The simple act of being witnessed by our friends transformed us.

We were better listeners.
We didn’t criticize each other.
We mirrored what the other was sharing.

Neither of us wanted to look like “the jerk” in front of our friends and it worked. We were both so n our best behavior. 

We ended up getting to a place of mutual understanding and resolution fairly quickly.

Even if yoy have some of the tools to communicate consciously and navigate conflict, we’ve all had that feeling of getting triggered and slipping back into unconstructive judgments, argumentation and defensiveness. 

Even when we know we’re not doing it the way we know we’re supposed to, it can be difficult to stop, take a breath and come back to center.

This is where a “relationship council” can come in handy. Shoutout @baya_voce for this concept/name. 

A relationship council, is a chosen group of people that you select to hold and support your relationship. 

One of the primary ways they can support, is by simply holding space during a challenging conversation.

They don’t need to be a trained therapist or coach, just someone who is there to provide loving accountability for each of you to be the best version of yourselves, especially when it gets hard.

Long story short, let your friends watch.

Loved joining @tuesdayswithmorrisey to talk about Social Flow and Relational Leadership. 

One of the most important lessons I’ve learned while developing Social Flow and Relational Leadership is that that authenticity isn't just about being true to ourselves. 

It's a act of service we offer to others.

When we are authentic, we create a safe space for others to do the same. It creates a ripple effect that fosters genuine connections and trust.

By being our authentic selves, we grant permission to those around us to drop their guards. This doesn't just build rapport; it cultivates deep respect and trust.

Authenticity in our interactions, be it in leadership, meeting people, or personal relationships, acts like a mirror, reflecting back the honesty and integrity we want to see in the world.

Think of the last time you interacted with someone who was unapologetically themselves. How did that make you feel? Inspired? Liberated? Valued? That's the power of authenticity. It's not just about being true to ourselves; it's about inspiring others to discover their authenticity as well.

As I continue on my journey, both personally and professionally, my mission remains clear: To not only be authentic, but to encourage and empower others to embrace their authentic selves as the most effective pathway to meaningful connection, success and fulfillment.

It's through this authenticity that we will build a world of deeper understanding, respect, and strong relationships.

Authenticity = service.

El Salvador has undergone quite the transformation recently. Growing up, I mostly heard about El Salvador when people were talking about the gangs and murder rate.

Since president Bukele came into power in 2019, he has thrown thousands of gang members into prison, embraced bitcoin as legal tender, and attempted to turn El Salvador into a top-tier Surf travel destination…all the locals I spoke with say it’s working.

What surf city lacks in vibe and healthy places to eat, it makes up for in, well….surf.

I don’t know anywhere else on earth that has so many incredible breaks within 30 minutes of each other.

We stayed at @balancesurfyoga - thanks to our new friends @lindsaygonzalezyoga and Adrian for the hospitality, keeping us nourished and showing us all the best spots! Reach out to these folks if you are planning a trip. 

Day 1 - el zonte

perfect intermediate break with an easy channel for paddling.  Go to betos for dinner on the cliff and get all the ceviches.

Day 2 - k61 
Had one of my favorite days surfing in years here. Another intermediate right hander with plenty of people available to film on the cliffs.  Go eat at vikingo and talk to the heavily tattooed owner who you can’t miss.

Day 3 - Sunzal 

You can walk to this break if you stay in El Tunco. Long paddle out, but a great, long beginner wave to learn on inside and fun for intermediate riders out the back. 

Day 4 - La bocana 

This is one of the only lefts in surf city, and it is right out front of Balancé resort. Pretty amazing to get this quality of wave with only 5-6 people out. Faster and barreling. Go to jungle cafe for dinner.

Day 5 - Tamanique waterfall

Mel and I were both surprised with how much we enjoyed this 2 hour hike and visit to the Falls. Not that many people there, spots for cliff diving and clean waters for swimming. It’s only a 30 minute drive from downtown surf city.

One of the powerful themes that emerged at Junto #14 was integrity.

I believe personal integrity has three core components:

	1.	Living our values
	2.	Speaking authentically
	3.	Honoring our agreements

One place where we are most frequently out of integrity is in our relationships:

	•	We withhold something important
	•	We avoid the person or withdraw completely
	•	We break an agreement

I believe one of the most powerful pathways to reclaim our personal integrity is by focusing on bringing our relationships back into a state of wholeness and harmony.

The skills and growth required to do this are some of the most important and practical for succeeding in business and building a fulfilling life (communication, conflict resolution, emotional intelligence, etc.).

Throughout the weekend, the men stepped up to feel deeply, share courageously, and take action in their fractured or contentious relationships.

We were invited to check our stories and share the real thing, even if we thought it could trigger an adverse reaction.

I would consistently remind the men:

We do not control other people; we only control what we do.

If our goal is to be honest and we aren’t honoring it…

Is there ever a good reason for acting out of integrity with ourselves?

I don’t think there is.

When we command this level of integrity from ourselves, we start to naturally command it from the people around us.

It becomes harder to accept anything less than full alignment once we’ve started to taste the liberation and lightness that exists when we intentionally confront the things between us and our integrity.

If you’re curious about what a life of integrity and relational leadership feels like, come and join us at our next Men’s retreat in February (link in bio).

If you are looking for a Christmas gift for the man in your life or have an end-of-year personal development budget at work, now’s a great time to opt in. Offering $200 off with the code ‘JUNTOXMAS’ until 12/25.”

I had fun facilitating for the @fourroomsmastermind in Austin this week - opened with a Social Flow workshop (pictured above)

It’s always fun to see how 30 minutes of authentic connection and practical conversation tips can transform a gathering.

During the section on authenticity, (what is real for me now?) I explained the difference between authenticity and vulnerability.

“it’s only vulnerability when you perceive a threat to being authentic.”

In social situations, the threat that we are perceiving is usually that we could be judged, ostracized, or rejected.

When we share authenticity with intentionally, the opposite usually happens.

People trust us, feel at ease and appreciate our realness. They feel like they can be themselves around us.

I gave this group two prompts to share some authenticity with Intentionality…

1. What do I like most about myself? 

2. What’s a challenge I’m facing and what’s the opportunity in it? 

What I love about this question set is that it opens up the full spectrum of possibility for how people can feel. What’s going great AND what kinda sucks. Depth and levity.

When we start with questions like this, we give people permission to meet us wherever they’re at.

To make it easier for people to go deep quickly, I invite them to imagine  their best friends. I ask a question…

“Do you want them to be able to really celebrate what they like about themselves? Do you want them to feel safe to talk about their challenges honestly?

If so, go first.

Be you, so they can too.

—

If you have an event coming up and want to amplify the connection there, shoot me a message.

My mentor @dianacarsonchapman recently described happiness as the result of three core variables.

Safety, control and recognition.

Anytime I find myself in a state of reactivity (tension, anxiety, resistance), I ask myself where I perceive I am lacking one of these.

Almost always, it is connected to a thought, story or prediction about the future.

It helps me to return to a place of presence and enjoyment of what I am doing in the moment.

Diana stresses how important it is to internally reference these things if we want to cultivate sustainable happiness in our lives.

Safety
Control
Recognition

What do you think of this happiness formula?

The End of Year Fuck Yeahs!

I've been sitting in a weekly Men's Group with these guys for over a year now.

Several years ago, while living in NY, I initiated a small tradition which I have continued and shared with many other groups across the country.

It's called "The End of Year 'Fuck Yeahs.'"

The "Fuck Yeahs" create an opportunity for the guys in our group to boast about themselves with reckless abandon.

It's a chance to celebrate everything that went right that year:

- Their big wins
- Personal growth
- Overcoming challenges
- Memorable adventures and fun
- Successes in their relationships

If it meant something to them, this is the space to share it and honor it.

One thing I've learned from years of running @wetribute is that many people struggle to accept appreciation. They also find it difficult to celebrate themselves or share their victories for fear of appearing boastful or being judged.

When people feel they can celebrate their successes among us without envy or judgment, they instantly feel safer and more connected.

During the "F*ck Yeahs," we make it clear that this is not the time to be humble.

Before we begin, I encourage the guys to look around the room at the other men. I invite them to celebrate their victories in a way that mirrors how they want others to celebrate themselves. If we want them to embrace love and appreciation for themselves, we have to lead by example.

We make it silly, bordering on ridiculous to create an atmosphere where guys can truly let loose. We'll play entrance music and initiate a slow clap before each guy shares. Naturally, my introduction is the Chicago Bulls theme music.

We encourage the guys to exaggerate their tone and take up space.

Most importantly, the entire group participates in each share. After the person speaking shares something emphatically, the whole group responds in unison:

"F*CK YEAH!"

Whether you host the "End of Year 'Fuck Yeahs" with your community or family, or you simply want to connect with a friend on a deeper level, remember to ask them what went right this year.

Be the kind of person your friends can share their wins with.

This movement was born when a group of friends had the same realization at the same time on the same night. The realization was hysterically simple.

They realized that they were “alive.” And then they realized, “holy shit,” that’s pretty amazing.

Now, we can imagine you sitting there reading that last sentence and silently mouthing “Duh” to yourself. But before you mouth anything, we’d just ask that you take a second and query yourself the following: How much of your day is spent living in the base-line awareness that your very existence is a friggin’ miracle?

The reason I ask is because if I had to wager, I’d say it’s not nearly as much as the time you spent wishing your job was more fulfilling, that your parents were less annoying, that your partner was nicer, or that your kids were easier, the weather was better, your bank
account was fatter, that you were skinnier, the list goes on and on....

If you get depressed thinking about that, take heart. You’re not alone. Most of us do this.

We humans go through life with this sort of low-level hum of
dissatisfaction. It’s a big part of what makes us, us. In fact, it’s this drive to
change our circumstances, to improve, to hack our conditions, that has
helped us grow from small bands of hunter gatherers to larger agricultural
societies to the enormous, interdependent information-based mega-cities of today.

Yet all this thinking and emoting and striving and doing and struggling has
come at a terrible cost. We’ve lost the ability to do one very essential thing,
which is honor the “holy-shit- ness” of our of daily existence.

Why?

Perhaps because this precious gift called consciousness is so seamless and
glitch-free that for most of our lives we feel like it’s not enough. It’s almost too vanilla. So what do we do?

We pile thoughts, memories, resentments, hopes, expectations over it like
toppings at an ice cream sundae bar, until the bare miraculous fact of this “I am-ness” is completely covered.

It is our hope that these items can be a fun, thought-provoking, sense-
stimulating way to live the joyous reality of the one thing we should never forget…

Holy Shit, Were Alive.

Www.holyshitwerealive.com

In my experience, a clear connection to our purpose is one of the most sustainable sources of motivation available to us.

Have you ever heard of Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs? Did you know most people teach it incorrectly? 

In 1943, Abraham Maslow synthesized one of the most well-known theories in the history of human development. In a nutshell, he believed that human needs were hierarchical. To fulfill a higher need on the chart, we must first satisfy the more basic need. We start at the bottom with physiological needs like water, food, and safety, and work our way up to the very top with self-actualization, fulfilling our potential.

Well, did you know that this theory, one of the most widely recognized and revered, is not taught as Maslow intended it in most schools and universities around the United States to this day? That’s right.

After Maslow published his theory in 1943, it garnered wide acclaim and criticism. As his theory rose to prominence, Maslow shared his frustration at the thought of self-actualization being the final need in his pyramid because he felt it was inherently selfish and fleeting.

From Maslow’s personal journal, published posthumously: “I realized I’d rather leave it behind me. Just too sloppy & too easily criticizable. Going through my notes brought this unease to consciousness. It’s been with me for years. Meant to write & publish a self-actualization critique, but somehow never did.”

What most people don’t know is that nearly 30 years after publishing his Hierarchy of Needs, Maslow developed a friendship with another man who cared deeply about human motivation, Viktor Frankl.

A story about peeing in trash cans and the importance of setting impeccable agreements.

Hiro decided to take a pee in his trashcan two nights ago. Afterwards, we agreed that he would not pee in his trash can.

All good, or so I thought.

Last night, he decided to pee in a different trashcan in the house.

His excuse was that he “didn’t want it to go unused.”

Rather than tell him what the agreement was, I asked him if he would write out the agreement and draw me a picture of it. I wanted to make sure that we had concrete proof and buying for his commitment to the agreement.

The result is pictured above. 

As I write this, I am in the midst of facilitating an offsite for a fin-tech start up, and I smile at the parallels.

We spend so much of our time trying to point out the problem we see to get people to change.

We are much better served by focusing on solutions. 

The best way to do this is often with an objective agreement. when that can be easily tracked, and that both parties are excited to commit to.

Th this is a big part of the transition, from “to-me” leadership to “by-me” leadership.

Thanks for the reminder Hiro.

Travelogue: 24 hours in Singapore…

Singapore feels like a NYC and Las Vegas mashup.

Great restaurants everywhere and experiential art sprinkled throughout the city. Everyone says it and it’s true, the city is remarkably clean for 5.5m people. It was wild to be in the business district at rush hour and see no one jaywalking. 

When you get to the airport, take the time to walk over and see “The Jewel,” the massive waterfall dome instillation; it is spectacular and an ode to the city’s art-forward culture.

We stayed at the Marina Bay Sands, which is the hotel with the infinity pool that you see everyone sharing photos from (including us now!) - this hotel is right in the middle of everything and a great option if you are strapped for time. You can walk to the gardens, museums and bay attractions from here easily. 

We started out the day at The Art and Science Museum. Very cool interactive art, with much of it created by the incredible @teamlab. 

Then, we rented bikes and rode through the city towards Chinatown to walk around and do our best to avoid the durian vendors.

After that, we went to Maxwell to check out the hawker stands and ate at one of the two Michelin starred food stands in town. 

Next, we went back to the hotel to check out the infinity pool and rest up for dinner.

Dinner: we went to a tasting kitchen called @appetite that was teeny tiny and fun. Other good options are Bar Stories or Cloud Street. Or, walk around Amoy St and find something that speaks to you. 

Then, we headed over to Gardens by the Bay to walk around the flower dome. They have an install called “Cloud Forest” that hosts some of the most spectacular vertical gardens I’ve ever seen. 

There are two big art shows in this area every night around 7 and 8pm, The Super Trees and the laser water show. 

The Super Trees have a supremely Burningman feel to them. They play eclectic music and sync a solid LED show to them. Worth it.

From there, you can walk over to the bay for the laser light show. This is very similar to the Bellagio water fountains with a projection mapping element layered onto it.  We were supremely tired and watched from our room in the sands. 

Fin.
